name: Tourist Problem
description:
Iahub is a big fan of tourists. He wants to become a tourist himself, so he
planned a trip. There are n destinations on a straight road that Iahub wants
to visit. Iahub starts the excursion from kilometer 0. The n destinations are
described by a non-negative integers sequence a1, a2, ..., an. The number ak
represents that the kth destination is at distance ak kilometers from the
starting point. No two destinations are located in the same place. Iahub wants
to visit each destination only once. Note that, crossing through a destination
is not considered visiting, unless Iahub explicitly wants to visit it at that
point. Also, after Iahub visits his last destination, he doesn't come back to
kilometer 0, as he stops his trip at the last destination. The distance
between destination located at kilometer x and next destination, located at
kilometer y, is |x - y| kilometers. We call a "route" an order of visiting the
destinations. Iahub can visit destinations in any order he wants, as long as
he visits all n destinations and he doesn't visit a destination more than
once. Iahub starts writing out on a paper all possible routes and for each of
them, he notes the total distance he would walk. He's interested in the
average number of kilometers he would walk by choosing a route. As he got
bored of writing out all the routes, he asks you to help him. Input The first
line contains integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 10^5). Next line contains n distinct integers
a1, a2, ..., an (1 ≤ ai ≤ 10^7). Output Output two integers — the numerator
and denominator of a fraction which is equal to the wanted average number. The
fraction must be irreducible. Examples Input 3 2 3 5 Output 22 3 Note Consider
6 possible routes: [2, 3, 5]: total distance traveled: |2 – 0| + |3 – 2| + |5
– 3| = 5; [2, 5, 3]: |2 – 0| + |5 – 2| + |3 – 5| = 7; [3, 2, 5]: |3 – 0| + |2
– 3| + |5 – 2| = 7; [3, 5, 2]: |3 – 0| + |5 – 3| + |2 – 5| = 8; [5, 2, 3]: |5
– 0| + |2 – 5| + |3 – 2| = 9; [5, 3, 2]: |5 – 0| + |3 – 5| + |2 – 3| = 8. The
average travel distance is = = .
